qas.question: In what form do some viruses store their entire genome?
Why do the cellular hosts of some viruses not have to wait for transcription to synthesize their proteins?

answers.text: Because they use RNA to store genes

qas.question: What is one type of an RNA retrovirus?
What sort of transcription does the genome of HIV require before its proteins can be synthesized?
Besides viruses, where has RNA-mediated epigenetic inheritance been observed?

answers.text: in plants and very rarely in animals

context: Some viruses store their entire genomes <a0_0>in the form of RNA<a0_0/>, and contain no DNA at all. <a1_0>Because they use RNA to store genes<a1_0/>, their cellular hosts may synthesize their proteins as soon as they are infected and without the delay in waiting for transcription. On the other hand, RNA retroviruses, such as <a2_0>HIV<a2_0/>, require the <a3_0>reverse transcription<a3_0/> of their genome from RNA into DNA before their proteins can be synthesized. RNA-mediated epigenetic inheritance has also been observed <a4_0>in plants and very rarely in animals<a4_0/>.
